channel.title: Partials on Arc
channel.description: Recent content in Partials on Arc

item.description: The number of acknowledgments the producer requires the leader to have received before considering a request complete. Alowed values: 1: the leader will write the record to its local log but will respond without awaiting full acknowledgement from all followers. 0: the job will not wait for any acknowledgment from the server at all. -1: the leader will wait for the full set of in-sync replicas to acknowledge the record (safest).
An authentication map for authenticating with a remote service. See authentication documentation.
The base path that partition discovery should start with.
The JDBC batch size, which determines how many rows to insert per round trip. This can help performance on JDBC drivers. Default: 1000.
A list of host/port pairs to use for establishing the initial connection to the Kafka cluster. e.g. host1:port1,host2:port2,...
Whether to enable a bulk copy. This is currently only available for sqlserver targets but more targets can be added as drivers become available. Default: false.
Use a case-sensitive formatter. A case-insensitive formatter MMM will accept both JUL and Jul where case-sensitive will only only accept Jul. Default: false.

When loading a file two additional metadata fields are added to each record: _filename and _index (row number in the file). These fields are automatically included as they are very useful when trying to understand where certain data came from when consuming the data downstream. The computational cost of adding the _index column in a distributed execution engine like Spark means that sometimes it is not worth the time/expense of precisely resolving the row number.

The database column data types to use instead of the defaults, when creating the table. Data type information should be specified in the same format as CREATE TABLE columns syntax (e.g: “name CHAR(64), comments VARCHAR(1024)”). The specified types should be valid spark sql data types.

This is a JDBC writer related option. If specified, this option allows setting of database-specific table and partition options when creating a table (e.g., CREATE TABLE t (name string) ENGINE=InnoDB).
A custom string to use as delimiter. Required if delimiter is set to Custom.
Parameters to inject into the Cypher statement before executing. The parameters use the ${} format.
The formatters to try to convert this field based on the Java DateTimeFormatter patterns. Try to order this list so the values are arranged from most frequent to least frequent.
The type of delimiter in the file. Supported values: Comma, Pipe, DefaultHive. DefaultHive is ASCII character 1, the default delimiter for Apache Hive extracts. Default: Comma.
An optional stage description to help document job files and print to job logs to assist debugging.
A list of environments under which this stage will be executed. See environments documentation.
A list of values which are considered as false. Try to order this list so the values are arranged from most frequent to least frequent.
The JDBC fetch size, which determines how many rows to fetch per round trip. This can help performance on JDBC drivers which default to low fetch size (eg. Oracle with 10 rows).
The field name.
A string that uniquely identifies the group of consumer processes to which this consumer belongs. This will retain the offset of the job between executions.
HTTP Headers to set for the HTTP request. These are not limited to the Internet Engineering Task Force standard headers.
The hostname of the target service.
A optional unique identifier for this field. Ideally this is a GUID and should remain constant even when changing field attributes over time.

A map of the fields to be passed to the TensorFlow Serving service. This map describes the required input fields and their type and will be used to extract the correct field from the Spark DataFrame (by name). E.g. a to call a TensorFlow Serving instance which requires an input of customer_usage of type DT_DOUBLE this map will be used to take the field customer_usage from inputView and create the required request of data type DT_DOUBLE.
URI of the input file containing the SQL statement.
Name of incoming Spark dataset.

The transaction isolation level, which applies to current connection. It can be one of NONE, READ_COMMITTED, READ_UNCOMMITTED, REPEATABLE_READ, or SERIALIZABLE, corresponding to standard transaction isolation levels defined by JDBC’s Connection object, with default of READ_UNCOMMITTED. Please refer the documentation in java.sql.Connection.
The JDBC URL to connect to. e.g., jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306.

Metadata to attach to the column. Basic JSON types string, double, long, object and array are supported. With array types the values must be all of the same type (i.e. [true, false] works but [true, 0] will not).
The name of the TensorFlow Serving model.
The Event Hubs namespace.
An optional value that a null value input value is replaced with before typing.
Whether the field is allowed to be nullable. Will throw fatal exception if this constraint is not met.

Values which when found will be converted to null. This is generally used for converting text serialisation formats back to correct null data types. This conversion is executed prior to nullable check.
The number of partitions that will be used for controlling parallelism.

The formatters to try to convert this field based on the Java DecimalFormat patterns. Try to order this list so the values are arranged from most frequent to least frequent. Formatters be used to specify uncommon number formats such as #,##0.###;#,##0.###- for a decimal with trailing minus sign or #,##0.###;(#,##0.###) for a decimal where the negative is displayed in accounting format with brakets instead of minus sign.

A map of the fields to be retrieved from the TensorFlow Serving service. This map describes which fields are expected to be returned from the TensorFlow Serving call and will be appended to the outputView.
Name of the constructed graph in the catalog. Graph will be accessible via ‘session.[outputGraph]‘.
Name of outgoing Spark dataset after processing.
Map of configuration parameters.
Columns to partition the data by.
A set of Key/Value that will be encoded as JSON and send to the HTTP server.
Whether to persist dataset to Spark cache. Will also log row count. Default: false.
The port of the target service.

A list expressions suitable for inclusion in WHERE clauses; each one defines one partition of the DataFrame to allow explicit parallel reads. e.g. ['id=1', 'id=2', 'id=3', 'id=4'] would create 4 parallel readers.
The row tag of your XML files to treat as a row. For example, in this XML: <books><book>1</book><book>2</book></books> the appropriate value would be book.
The mode for writing the output file to describe how errors are handled. Available options are: Append, ErrorIfExists, Ignore, Overwrite. Default is Overwrite if not specified.

Used for multiple purposes: Can be used to set metadata on a the extracted DataFrame. Note this will overwrite the existing metadata if it exists. Can be used to specify a schema in case of no input files. This stage will create an empty DataFrame with this schema so any downstream logic that depends on the columns in this dataset, e.g. SQLTransform, is still able to run. This feature can be used to allow deployment of business logic that depends on a dataset which has not been enabled by an upstream sending system.
Similar to schemaURI but allows the schema to be passed in as another DataFrame. It takes precedence over schemaURI if provided.
The Event Hubs Shared Access Signature Key.
The Event Hubs Shared Access Signature Key Name.
The name of the TensorFlow Serving signature.
A SQL statement to execute.
Parameters to inject into the SQL statement before executing. The parameters use the ${} format.
Name of the stage for logging.
The JDBC table that should be read. Note that anything that is valid in a FROM clause of a SQL query can be used, e.g. (SELECT * FROM sourcetable WHERE key=value) sourcetable or just sourcetable.
The target Kafka topic.
Trim the field prior to data typing attempts.
A list of values which are considered as true. Try to order this list so the values are arranged from most frequent to least frequent.
If using SaveMode equal to Overwrite, this additional option causes Spark to TRUNCATE TABLE of existing data instead of executing a DELETE FROM statement.
The data type to convert the field to. Supported values: boolean, date, decimal, double, integer, long, string, timestamp.
A list of valid status codes which will result in a successful stage if the list contains the HTTP server response code. If not provided the default values are [200, 201, 202].
A structured streaming watermark object. Requires eventTime and delayThreshold attributes.
